titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the I Love New York Spring Festival ephemera and memorabilia collection ARC.277
titlestmt.author: Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-08-25 13:52:21 +0000.

did.unittitle: I Love New York Spring Festival ephemera and memorabilia collection

physdesc.extent: in one half manuscript box and oversize box.

did.abstract: This collection contains ephemera and memorabilia disseminated for the 1992 I Love New York Spring Festival in Brooklyn.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Minimally processed to the collection level.
The collection combines the accessions 1992.011 and 1992.032.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. Formally accessioned in 1992.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); I Love New York Spring Festival ephemera and memorabilia collection, ARC.277, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains ephemera and memorabilia disseminated for the 1992 I Love New York Spring Festival in Brooklyn. Items include press releases, brochures, and posters related to festival events, as well as organizations such as the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, the Brooklyn Historical Society, and the Brooklyn Museum. A souvenir bag, wall calendar, and button are also included.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The I Love New York Spring Festival took place in Brooklyn from May 21 to June 21, 1992 and was a publicity campaign to generate increased interest and tourism in the borough of Brooklyn. The festival highlighted Brooklyn's iconic landmarks, neighborhoods, parks, arts and cultural organizations, and restaurants.
